pull_request.title: Deprecate some common::Color in favor of ign-math

pullrequest.title: Deprecate some common::Color in favor of ign-math

content.raw:
I wasn't sure how to handle this one. The function is deprecated, but if we have a compiler warning, it is triggered whenever the `msgs::ConvertAny` function is used in a template like [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/60af908626f20a5c5a3753e996b3e376101ffd1d/gazebo/util/IntrospectionManager.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#IntrospectionManager.hh-58).

I thought of suppressing the deprecation warning there, but this would mean downstream users would need to do the same, even though there's nothing wrong with their code, so I thought this wasn't ideal.

The solution I came up with was, as described above, to print a [runtime warning](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2818/deprecate-some-common-color-in-favor-of/diff#Lgazebo/msgs/msgs.ccT320) if the `common::Color` function is used. I don't think this is ideal either, though.

Do you have a better idea? I don't remember running into this kind of situation before.
content.html:
I wasn't sure how to handle this one. The function is deprecated, but if we have a compiler warning, it is triggered whenever the msgs::ConvertAny function is used in a template like here.

I thought of suppressing the deprecation warning there, but this would mean downstream users would need to do the same, even though there's nothing wrong with their code, so I thought this wasn't ideal.

The solution I came up with was, as described above, to print a runtime warning if the common::Color function is used. I don't think this is ideal either, though.

Do you have a better idea? I don't remember running into this kind of situation before.
